column3:
While it may seem like we have everything figured out about mobile with the iPhone form factor now cemented in our daily lives, in reality, we are in the early stages of the current mobile renaissance. Consumers are still trying to figure out what sizes of glass should be carried in our pockets or worn on our bodies. Despite all of these changes, there's one theme that has remained unwavering: technology is becoming more personalized. With Apple Watch, Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is placing a big bet that a device for the wrist is the next progression of personalized technology, which inherently adds an element of luxury and fashion to the mix. The Apple Watch keynote wasn't perfect, but management took the opportunity to tweak its marketing message a bit with the goal of positioning the Apple Watch as the newest, most personal device in the iOS product portfolio. The Apple Watch has the potential to be positioned as the primary interface for mobile computing.

Unchartered Territory

If there was one moment of Apple's "Spring forward" keynote that should stand out it occurred at the 52-minute mark. Up to that point, the presentation was classic Apple. After a little bit of Apple TV news, Jeff Williams introduced a new health research platform that came across as something only Apple would be able to do, and Phil Schiller was up on stage, gleefully explaining why the new MacBook was the best Mac ever imagined. For the first 52 minutes of the event, Apple was at its best, and it showed. When the discussion turned to Apple Watch, Tim Cook and Kevin Lynch spent the next 42 minutes talking about all of the things Apple Watch can do, but the presentation lacked the same level of cohesiveness that was found in the beginning slides. Aegerion Pharmaceuticals (AEGR) is a small biopharmaceutical company dedicated to developing therapies for debilitating rare diseases. It has a market cap of $798.82 million and on Feb. 26 reported its financial results and business highlights for the fourth quarter and full year of 2014. It now markets two products after launching its new acquisition Myalept (metreleptin) in late January 2015.

Key products:

Aegerion's core product is Juxtapid (sold as Lojuxta in Europe), a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor indicated as an adjunct to a low-fat diet and other lipid-lowering treatments to reduce low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C or "bad" cholesterol), total cholesterol, apolipoprotein B and non-high-density lipoprotein cholesterol in patients with homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (HoFH). HoFH is the most severe of the inherited forms of hypercholesterolemia (high levels of LDL-C). Patients with a mutated LDLR gene in either of their #19 chromosomes will have the milder heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (HeFH); if both chromosomes are altered, they have HoFH. HeFH parents have a 50% chance to pass on that altered gene to any of their children. Unfortunately, each HoFH patient's children will automatically have at least HeFH. The LDLR mutation reduces the number of LDL receptors, which normally bind to LDL-C and remove the excess from the body. In HoFH, the excess cholesterol deposits in eyelids, skin, joints, and tendons, and usually ends with the patients' early death (before age 30) from heart attacks. HoFH has an estimated prevalence of 1 in 1 million people. Aegerion is in the process of finalizing the protocol of a planned pediatric and adolescent HoFH trial, which they hope to initiate mid-2015.

Myalept was initially launched by AstraZeneca (AZN) in June 2014. The leptin analog is a replacement therapy to treat the complications of leptin deficiency in patients with acquired or congenital generalized lipodystrophy. Both are
